item.description:
NPR's From the Top returns to New England Conservatory's Jordan Hall in Boston on Sunday, March 29, 2009 at 2pm to tape a national radio broadcast of brilliant young musicians. Parties of 8 or more are eligible for discount pricing, so please pay $16 (NEW PRICE) via Paypal on this page by March 15th so I can reserve seats for us in time. We just got a better discount rate.. as long as there are at least 8 of us. We need to get there by 1. 30 pm.

ABOUT THE PERFORMERS: Talent from the Boston-area will include 15-year-old cellist Aaron Wolff from Newton, MA and the Boston Children’s Chorus. Aaron Wolff is the son of New England Conservatory’s Director of Orchestras, Hugh Wolff, and will be featured in the Coen Brothers’ upcoming release, “A Serious Man.” The Newton South freshman will perform Popper’s Hungarian Rhapsody. The Boston Children’s Chorus brings together singers in grades 2-12 from 50 of Boston’s urban and suburban neighborhoods. Under the direction of Artistic Director Anthony Trecek-King, the chorus has performed in Chicago, Oregon, Mexico, at the Democratic National Convention, with the Boston Pops and on the annually televised Martin Luther King, Jr. Concert. The concert will also feature Mackenzie Hammel, a 17-year-old harpist from Cincinnati, OH playing selections from Suite of Eight Dances by Carlos Salzedo, flutist Alison Beskin, 18, from Atlanta, GA performing the second movement of Henri Dutilleux’s Sonatine, and Clifton Williams, a 17-year-old pianist from Washington, D.C who is a recipient of From the Top’s $10,000 Jack Kent Cooke Young Artist Award. This episode will broadcast on WGBH 89.7 FM on Saturday, May 2 at 11am and Sunday, May 3 at 6pm.

Let's go for a drink or a tea/coffee after the show!
item.how_to_find_us: Foyer, look for red scarf (pls post your photo so I can look for you too!)
item.name: From the Top live NPR show from Jordan Hall
